description: From Latin silƒìns (‚Äúsilent‚Äù), present participle of sile≈ç (‚Äúbe silent‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *seyl- (‚Äústill, windless, quiet, slow‚Äù). Related to Gothic êå∞êåΩêå∞êçÉêåπêåªêå∞êåΩ (anasilan, ‚Äúto cease, grow still, be silent‚Äù), Old English sƒÅlnes (‚Äúsilence‚Äù).

adjectives.description: silent (comparative silenter or more silent, superlative silentest or most silent)

entries.meaning: Free from sound or noise; absolutely still; perfectly quiet.
examples: What was formerly performed by fleets and armies, by invasions, sieges, and battles, has been of late accomplished by more silent methods.

entries.meaning: Not speaking; indisposed to talk; speechless; mute; taciturn; not loquacious; not talkative.
Keeping at rest; inactive; calm; undisturbed.
examples: The winds were silent, all the waves asleep, / And heaven was trac'd upon the flattering deep

entries.meaning: (pronunciation) Not pronounced; having no sound; quiescent.
examples: The e is silent in fable.
Silent letters can make some words difficult to spell.
The ‚Äúl‚Äù in the English word "salmon" is silent.

entries.meaning: Having no effect; not operating; inefficient.
(technology) With the sound turned off; usually on silent or in silent mode.

examples: The Magnavox Odyssey was a silent console.
a silent voter; a silent partner

entries.meaning: Of an edit or change to a text, not explicitly acknowledged.
(genetics) Not implying significant modifications which would affect a peptide sequence.
Undiagnosed or undetected because of an absence of symptoms.
Of distilled spirit: having no flavour or odour.
(uncountable) That which is silent; a time of silence.
